Legal_Issue: Likelihood of confusion between POLYSORB and POLYSOFT trademarks for shoe insoles
Evidence_Assessment: Credibility issues with consumer confusion evidence
Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiff must prove likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: Need for viva voce testimony due to credibility concerns
Legal_Rule: Confusion occurs when use of a trademark leads to inference of same source
Procedural_Issue: Appropriateness of summary judgment given factual disputes
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendant's use of POLYSOFT infringes plaintiff's POLYSORB trademark
Outcome_on_Merits: No final determination; genuine issue for trial
Review_Standard: Palpable and overriding error standard may apply on appeal
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Fairness preserved by requiring trial for credibility assessment
Key_Evidence_Considered: Similarity in sound/appearance of marks, identical product (insoles), trade overlap
Legal_Framework: Trade-marks Act, Canadian common law on passing-off
Applicant_Challenge: Defendant sought dismissal via summary judgment
Court_Result: Motion dismissed, case proceeds to trial
Defendant_Response: Denial of confusion and challenge to plaintiff's evidence
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, affidavit evidence, consumer perception
Remedy_Requested: Summary judgment in favor of defendant
Outcome: Plaintiff awarded costs, case to proceed to trial
Remedy_Sought: Injunction, damages, or other relief at trial
Authority: Trade-marks Act, Canadian jurisprudence on trademark confusion
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation of trademark infringement and passing-off
Outcome_of_Review: Appeal not yet filed; motion denied
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Trial pending on merits of infringement
